repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
e.g. with the allocator specified, or with a hash function or predicate etc. It needs to generate a separate version of the conversion code for each variation of the container.

Fixes #4166

comment_data.body:
It's interesting that the style checker didn't complain here (also in the other places that use `…+…`).
```suggestion
                optional_arg_template_names = "," + optional_arg_template_names
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3787,24 +3787,39 @@ def create_from_py_utility_code(self, env):
             X = "XYZABC"
             tags = []
             context = {}
+            optional_tags = []
+            optional_tag_strs = []
+            optional_arg_template_names = []  # these may be different (e.g. for unordered_map, map)
+                # hence have to be generated here rather than hard-coded in the utility_code
             for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
                 if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
-                    break
+                    optional_arg_template_names.append("%s=*" % self.template_type.templates[ix].name)
+                    if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                        optional_tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                        optional_tag_strs.append(X[ix])
+                        context[X[ix]] = T
+                    continue
                 if T.is_pyobject or not T.create_from_py_utility_code(env):
                     return False
                 tags.append(T.specialization_name())
                 context[X[ix]] = T
 
             if self.cname in cpp_string_conversions:
                 cls = 'string'
-                tags = type_identifier(self),
+                tags = [type_identifier(self)]
             else:
                 cls = self.cname[5:]
-            cname = '__pyx_convert_%s_from_py_%s' % (cls, '__and_'.join(tags))
+            optional_tag_strs = ",".join(optional_tag_strs)
+            optional_arg_template_names = ",".join(optional_arg_template_names)
+            if optional_arg_template_names:
+                optional_arg_template_names = ","+optional_arg_template_names

comment_data.body: (Ah, I know – we have stuff like `n+1` in the code base, without whitespace, which is … ok, but rules out enabling the code style checks for arithmetic operators. Too bad…)

comment_data.body:
This casting away the const feels slightly dubious to me.

It's because Cython infers the iterator type from `begin`, I wonder if it should try `const_begin` first for const types, but that feels like a separate change.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -136,34 +103,22 @@ cdef object {{cname}}(const cpp_list[X]& v):
 
 #################### set.from_py ####################
 
-cdef extern from *:
-    cdef cppclass set "std::{{maybe_unordered}}set" [T]:
-        void insert(T&) except +
-
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef set[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
-    cdef set[X] s
+cdef Tp {{cname}}(object o) except *:
+    cdef Tp s
     for item in o:
-        s.insert(<X>item)
+        s.insert(<Tp.value_type>item)
     return s
 
 
 #################### set.to_py ####################
 
 cimport cython
 
-cdef extern from *:
-    cdef cppclass cpp_set "std::{{maybe_unordered}}set" [T]:
-        cppclass const_iterator:
-            T& operator*()
-            const_iterator operator++()
-            bint operator!=(const_iterator)
-        const_iterator begin()
-        const_iterator end()
-
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef object {{cname}}(const cpp_set[X]& s):
-    return {v for v in s}
+cdef object {{cname}}(const Tp& s):
+    # casting away the const is a bit dubious, but helps Cython do the iteration
+    return {v for v in <Tp&>s}

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                # not all template types are convertible
                return None
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3780,31 +3780,39 @@ def can_coerce_from_pyobject(self, env):
             return True
         return False
 
+    def _get_conversion_tags_context_cls(self, env, tags, context):
+        # modifies tags and context, returns the cls name or False (if it's not convertible)
+        for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
+            if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
+                if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                    tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                continue
+            if not T.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
+                return False

comment_data.body: The method is called `_get_…` but changes its input arguments. That seems fishy. There's more than one function in here, I'd say.

+        context['Tp'] = self

comment_data.body:
Possibly this should be split into a validation function that just does

```
<loop>:
    if not T.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
        return False
```

and a tag/context/cname generation function that does the rest. Which is possibly what you meant by:

> ISTM that the loop over the templates is really two separate loops, for example.

I'll wait to see how much this change breaks first though
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+        # modifies tags and context, returns the cls name or False (if it's not convertible)
+        for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
+            if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
+                if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                    tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                continue

+                return False
+            tags.append(T.specialization_name())

comment_data.body: Did you really mean to use `Tp` as a type name here? Does that work?

comment_data.body:
This condition seems slightly odd to me - T being an `object` shouldn't prevent conversion to/from Python.

However, since Cython doesn't handle C++ containers of `object` I think it's largely hypothetical so it's doing no harm
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3776,32 +3776,62 @@ def can_coerce_from_pyobject(self, env):
             return True
         return False
 
+    def _get_conversion_context_cls_cname(self, cname_format_str):
+        # cname_format_str is passed "prefix", "format", "tags"
+        X = "XYZABC"
+        tags = []
+        context = {}
+        optional_tag_strs = []
+        optional_arg_template_names = ['']  # these may be different (e.g. for unordered_map, map)
+            # hence have to be generated here rather than hard-coded in the utility_code.
+            # Start with an empty string so that the joined output starts with ','
+        for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
+            if ix < builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
+                tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                context[X[ix]] = T
+            else:
+                optional_arg_template_names.append("%s=*" % self.template_type.templates[ix].name)
+                if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                    tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                    optional_tag_strs.append(X[ix])
+                    context[X[ix]] = T
+
+        optional_tag_strs = ",".join(optional_tag_strs)
+        optional_arg_template_names = ",".join(optional_arg_template_names)
+
+        if self.cname in cpp_string_conversions:
+            cls = 'string'
+            prefix = 'PyObject_'  # gets specialised by explicit type casts in CoerceToPyTypeNode
+            tags = [type_identifier(self)]
+        else:
+            cls = self.cname[5:]
+            prefix = ''
+
+        cname = cname_format_str.format(prefix=prefix, cls=cls, tags='__and_'.join(tags))
+
+        context.update({
+            'cname': cname,
+            'maybe_unordered': self.maybe_unordered(),
+            'type': self.cname,
+            'optional_template_args': optional_tag_strs,
+            'optional_template_names': optional_arg_template_names,
+        })
+        return context, cls, cname
+
     def create_from_py_utility_code(self, env):
         if self.from_py_function is not None:
             return True
-        if self.cname in builtin_cpp_conversions or self.cname in cpp_string_conversions:
-            X = "XYZABC"
-            tags = []
-            context = {}
-            for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
-                if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
-                    break
+        if self.cname in builtin_cpp_conversions:
+            # check that it's possible to convert all the relevant templates
+            # only scan the stored types; don't scan to hash types, comparison types, operators, etc.
+            for T in (self.templates or [])[:builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]]:
                 if T.is_pyobject or not T.create_from_py_utility_code(env):

comment_data.body: `cls` is the typical thing that you find in classmethods. Let's invest a couple of characters into clarity and name this `cpp_class`.

comment_data.body: How do we actually know that there won't be more than six template parameters? What happens if a user erroneously adds more?

             return True

+        X = "XYZABC"

comment_data.body:
I was thinking more of something like this, to make it clearer that we're really doing two separate things in two separate loops here:

```suggestion
        if self.templates:
            templates = list(zip(self.templates, X, self.template_type.templates))
            builtin_template_count = builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]

            for T, template_name, _ in templates[:builtin_template_count]:
                tags.append(T.specialization_name())
                context[template_name] = T

            for T, template_name, type_template in templates[builtin_template_count:]:
                optional_arg_template_names.append("%s=*" % type_template.name)
                if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
                    tags.append(T.specialization_name())
                    optional_tag_strs.append(template_name)
                    context[template_name] = T
```
(Not sure if `type_template` is a good name… not even sure what it is, right now.)

comment_data.body: I've changed it now to generate extra arguments T1, T2, T3 etc are needed
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body:
Hmm. That now makes it even less clear what is to be returned (it's not 5 things, it's just 3).
Why not just `_prepare_conversion_context()`? It returns more, sure, but that's still part of the context, sort-of.

I mean, in the end, this is a prime example of a function that does too much, and the obvious solution would be to slice it up into, say, four or five functions. It's just that we don't need those, really.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3776,7 +3776,7 @@ def can_coerce_from_pyobject(self, env):
             return True
         return False
 
-    def _get_conversion_context_cls_cname(self, cname_format_str):
+    def _get_conversion_context_cpp_cls_name_cname(self, cname_format_str):

commit.message:
Conversion of C++ containers with optional templates

e.g. with the allocator specified, or with a hash function or
predicate etc. It needs to generate a separate version of the
conversion code for each variation of the container.

Fixes #4166
Use converted type directly rather than redeclaring it

Revert "Use converted type directly rather than redeclaring it"

This reverts commit 86915c49caee9f03b82d82f27d1dbf5af12effae.
Factored out parts covered by can_coerce functions
Fixed extra template names and variable name

title: Conversion of C++ containers with optional templates
